0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Cystinosis, Nephropathic: (immediate-release) initial, one-quarter to one-sixth of maintenance dose ORALLY; slowly increase dose over 4 to 6 weeks to maintenance dose of 2 g/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses
  • Cystinosis, Nephropathic: (delayed-release) initial, one-sixth to one-quarter of maintenance dose ORALLY; slowly increase dose over 4 to 6 weeks to maintenance dose of 1.3 g/m(2)/day ORALLY in 2 divided doses administered every 12 hours; MAX dose, 1.95 g/m(2)/day
  • Cystinosis, Nephropathic: (delayed-release) conversion from immediate release, administer total daily dose of immediate-release cysteamine ORALLY in 2 divided doses 12 hours apart

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• (delayed-release) safety and efficacy not established in children younger than 6 years
  • Cystinosis, Nephropathic: (immediate-release) initial, one-quarter to one-sixth of maintenance dose ORALLY; slowly increase over 4 to 6 weeks to maintenance dose of 1.3 g/m(2)/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses (age up to 12 years) or 2 g/day in 4 divided doses (age over 12 years and 110 pounds (55 kg))
  • Cystinosis, Nephropathic: (delayed-release) 6 years or older, initial, one-sixth to one-quarter of maintenance dose ORALLY; slowly increase dose over 4 to 6 weeks to maintenance dose of 1.3 g/m(2)/day ORALLY in 2 divided doses administered every 12 hours; MAX dose, 1.95 g/m(2)/day
  • Cystinosis, Nephropathic: (delayed-release) 6 years or older, conversion from immediate release, administer total daily dose of immediate-release cysteamine ORALLY in 2 divided doses 12 hours apart

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• benign intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri), with or without papilledema, may occur; monitoring recommended
  • CNS symptoms, including lethargy, somnolence, and depression, may occur; monitoring recommended; interruption of therapy or dose reductions may be warranted
  • encephalopathy may occur; monitoring recommended; interruption of therapy or dose reductions may be warranted
  • gastrointestinal bleeding and ulceration may occur
  • gastrointestinal tract adverse effects, including nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and abdominal pain, may occur; interruption of therapy or dose adjustment may be necessary with severe symptoms
  • leukopenia may occur; monitoring recommended
  • liver function test abnormalities, particularly elevations of alkaline phosphatase, may occur; monitoring recommended
  • papilledema may occur; monitoring recommended
  • seizures may occur; monitoring recommended; interruption of therapy or dose reductions may be warranted
  • skin and bone lesions (ie, molluscoid pseudotumors, skin striae, osteopenia, compression fractures, scoliosis, genu valgum) with joint hyperextension and leg pain, resembling clinical features of Ehler-Danlos syndrome, may occur; increased risk with high doses; monitoring recommended; therapy interruption and dose adjustment recommended
  • skin rash, severe, including erythema multiforme bullosa and toxic epidermal necrolysis, may occur; permanently discontinue use
  • skin rashes may occur; therapy interruption and dose adjustment recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Cysteamine: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Finding of odor of skin (delayed-release, at least 5%), Rash (immediate-release, 7%; delayed release, at least 5%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (delayed-release, 14%), Breath smells unpleasant (delayed-release, at least 5%), Diarrhea (immediate release, 16%; delayed-release, at least 5%), Loss of appetite (immediate-release, 5% to 31%; delayed-release, 2% to greater than or equal to 5%), Nausea (immediate-release, up to 7%; delayed-release, up to 16%), Vomiting (immediate-release, 12% to 35%; delayed-release, up to 19%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (delayed-release, 5% or greater), Headache (delayed-release, up to 9%), Lethargy (immediate-release, 11%)
  • Other:Fever (immediate-release, 22%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme, Skin lesion, Skin striae, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal hemorrhage, Gastrointestinal ulcer
  • Hematologic:Leukopenia
  • Musculoskeletal:Fracture of bone, Hyperextension, Osteopenia, Pain in lower limb, Scoliosis deformity of spine
  • Neurologic:CNS symptom, Encephalopathy, Pseudotumor cerebri, Seizure, Somnolence
  • Ophthalmic:Papilledema - optic disc edema due to raised intracranial pressure

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Cysteamine bitartrate is a cystine depleting agent which reduces the cystine content of cells in cystinotic patients. It takes part in a thiol-disulfide interchange reaction within lysosomes as it converts cystine into cysteine and cysteine-cysteamine mixed disulfide, both of which can exit the lysosome in cystinotic patients.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Tmax, Oral, delayed-release: 2.78 hours:
  • Tmax, Oral, immediate-release: 1.4 hours
  • Effect of food, delayed-release: reduced systemic exposure

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • (immediate-release) do not administer intact capsules to children under the age of approximately 6 years due to risk of aspiration; may administer by sprinkling capsule contents over food
  • (delayed-release) administer at least 30 minutes before and 2 hours after meals; if necessary, 4 ounces (one-half cup) of food may be eaten 1 hour before and 1 hour after administration
  • (delayed-release) swallow capsules whole; do not crush or chew
  • (delayed-release) capsules may be opened and granules sprinkled on 4 ounces apple sauce or berry jelly, or mixed with 4 ounces of orange or apple juice
  • (delayed-release) may be administered via gastrostomy tube 12 French or larger by sprinkling granules on 4 ounces of applesauce, then flushing tube with 8 ounces orange or apple juice
  • take food or juice mixture within 30 minutes of preparation

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• leukocyte cystine levels; at least every 3 months (immediate-release); monthly for 3 months then quarterly for 12 months, then at least twice per year, in cysteamine-naive patients (delayed-release); every 2 weeks then quarterly for 6 months then at least twice yearly, in patients switching from immediate-release (delayed-release)
  • serum creatinine and electrolytes, 24-hour urinary protein, creatinine clearance
  • physical examination for body weight and growth velocity; every 4 months
  • ophthalmological examination
  • alkaline phosphatase
  • blood counts
  • hepatic function
  • skin or bone lesions
  • gastrointestinal bleeding or ulceration signs and symptoms
  • symptoms of benign intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri) and/or papilledema; headache, tinnitus, dizziness, nausea, diplopia, blurry vision, loss of vision, pain behind the eye, or pain with eye movement
  • signs of serious skin rash

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Cystagon
    Oral Capsule: 50 MG, 150 MG
  • Procysbi
    Oral Capsule, Delayed Release: 25 MG, 75 MG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness, lethargy, or somnolence.
  • Tell patient to immediately report symptoms of benign intracranial hypertension (ie, headaches, tinnitus, nausea, diplopia, blurred or loss of vision, eye pain).
  • Counsel patient to report CNS symptoms such as seizures, depression, and encephalopathy.
  • Drug may cause abdominal pain, anorexia, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, or headaches.
  • Warn patient to report symptoms of erythema multiforme or toxic epidermal necrolysis.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report symptoms of gastrointestinal ulcers or bleeding.
  • Counsel patient to take delayed-release capsule at least 2 hours after and 30 minutes before a meal. If needed, patient can consume 4 ounces of food 1 hour before or after dose. Take consistently with regard to food and avoid high-fat foods close to dosing.
  • Advise caregiver of child younger than 6 years of age to open immediate-release capsule and sprinkle contents over food.
  • Instruct patient taking the immediate-release capsule to take a missed dose as soon as possible. If the next dose is within 2 hours, skip the missed dose and resume a regular schedule.
  • Advise patient taking the delayed-release capsule to take a missed dose as soon as possible. If the next dose is within 4 hours, skip the missed dose and resume a regular schedule.
